ud1.10:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ud1.10:1.3: Now at that time Bāhiya of the Bark Cloth was residing by Suppāraka on the ocean shore, where he was honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And he received robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
ud1.10:1.4: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,
ud1.10:1.5: “I am one of those in the world who are perfected or on the path to perfection.”
ud1.10:2.1: Then a deity who was a former relative of Bāhiya, having sympathy and wanting what’s best for him, approached him and said:
ud1.10:2.2: “Bāhiya, you’re not a perfected one, nor on the path to perfection.
ud1.10:2.3: You don’t have the practice by which you might become a perfected one or one on the path to perfection.”
ud1.10:3.1: “So who then are those in the world who are perfected or on the path to perfection?”
ud1.10:3.2: “In the northern lands there is a city named Sāvatthī.
ud1.10:3.3: There that Blessed One is now staying, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
ud1.10:3.4: He is a perfected one and teaches the Dhamma for the sake of perfection.”
ud1.10:4.1: Impelled by that deity, Bāhiya left Suppāraka right away.
ud1.10:4.2: Sojourning no more than a single night in any place, he made his way to Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery in the Jeta Grove at Sāvatthī.
ud1.10:4.3: At that time several mendicants were walking mindfully in the open air.
ud1.10:4.5: “Sirs, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?
ud1.10:4.6: For I want to see him.”
ud1.10:4.7: “He has entered an inhabited area for almsfood, Bāhiya.”
ud1.10:5.1: Then Bāhiya rushed out of the Jeta Grove and entered Sāvatthī, where he saw the Buddha walking for alms. He was impressive and inspiring, with peaceful faculties and heart, attained to the highest self-control and serenity, like an elephant with tamed, guarded, and controlled faculties.
ud1.10:5.2: Bāhiya went up to the Buddha, bowed down with his head at the Buddha’s feet, and said,
ud1.10:5.3: “Sir, let the Blessed One teach me the Dhamma! Let the Holy One teach me the Dhamma!
ud1.10:5.4: That would be for my lasting welfare and happiness.”
ud1.10:5.6: “It’s not the time, Bāhiya, so long as I have entered an inhabited area for almsfood.”
ud1.10:6.1: For a second time, Bāhiya said,
ud1.10:6.2: “But you never know, sir, when life is at risk, either the Buddha’s or my own.
ud1.10:6.3: Let the Blessed One teach me the Dhamma! Let the Holy One teach me the Dhamma!
ud1.10:6.4: That would be for my lasting welfare and happiness.”
ud1.10:6.5: For a second time, the Buddha said,
ud1.10:6.6: “It’s not the time, Bāhiya, so long as I have entered an inhabited area for almsfood.”
ud1.10:7.1: For a third time, Bāhiya said,
ud1.10:7.2: “But you never know, sir, when life is at risk, either the Buddha’s or my own.
ud1.10:7.3: Let the Blessed One teach me the Dhamma! Let the Holy One teach me the Dhamma!
ud1.10:7.4: That would be for my lasting welfare and happiness.”
ud1.10:8.1: “In that case, Bāhiya, you should train like this:
ud1.10:8.2: ‘In the seen will be merely the seen; in the heard will be merely the heard; in the thought will be merely the thought; in the known will be merely the known.’
ud1.10:8.4: When you have trained in this way,
ud1.10:8.9: you won’t be in this life or the next or between the two.
ud1.10:8.10: Just this is the end of suffering.”
ud1.10:9.1: Then, due to this brief Dhamma teaching of the Buddha, Bāhiya’s mind was right away freed from defilements by not grasping.
ud1.10:10.1: And when the Buddha had given Bāhiya this brief advice he left.
ud1.10:10.2: But soon after the Buddha had left, a cow with a baby calf charged at Bāhiya and took his life.
ud1.10:11.1: Then the Buddha wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he exited the city together with several mendicants and saw that Bāhiya had passed away.
ud1.10:11.3: “Mendicants, pick up Bāhiya’s corpse. Having lifted it onto a cot and carried it, cremate it and build a monument.
ud1.10:11.4: Mendicants, one of your spiritual companions has passed away.”
ud1.10:12.1: “Yes, sir,” replied those mendicants. They did as the Buddha asked, then returned to the Buddha
ud1.10:12.3: “Sir, Bāhiya’s corpse has been cremated and a monument built for him.
ud1.10:12.4: Where has he been reborn in his next life?”
ud1.10:12.5: “Mendicants, Bāhiya was astute. He practiced in line with the teaching, and did not trouble me about the teachings.
ud1.10:12.6: Bāhiya of the Bark Cloth has become fully quenched.”
ud1.10:13.1: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ud1.10:14.2: fire and air have no footing—
ud1.10:14.4: nor does the sun shed its light;
ud1.10:15.1: And when a sage, a brahmin, finds understanding
ud1.10:15.4: from pleasure and pain they are released.”
ud1.10:16.1: This too is a heartfelt saying that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.
